visuals: Start with a wide shot of a human body, zoom into a cellular level. A 3D molecular model of Hydrocortisone appears, highlighting its characteristic steroid backbone. Text overlay: 'Hydrocortisone'
narration: Hydrocortisone, a potent corticosteroid, acts as an anti-inflammatory by diffusing into cells...

visuals: Inside a cell, Hydrocortisone binds to the Glucocorticoid Receptor (NR3C1) in the cytoplasm. The complex translocates into the nucleus, binding to DNA, showing a visual representation of gene expression modulation (e.g., reduced production of inflammatory mediators).
narration: ...where it binds to the NR3C1 receptor. This complex then enters the nucleus, modulating gene expression to suppress inflammation.

scene: Introduction to Aspirin and its Primary Action
visuals: A new 3D molecular model of Aspirin appears, highlighting its acetyl group. Show Aspirin interacting with a platelet, specifically binding to and irreversibly acetylating Cyclooxygenase-1 (COX-1) enzyme, inhibiting its function.
narration: Aspirin, an NSAID, primarily inhibits cyclooxygenase enzymes, especially COX-1 in platelets, preventing their aggregation.

visuals: Transition to a simplified cross-section of the stomach lining. First, show Hydrocortisone's effect: reduced mucus layer. Next, show Aspirin's effect: direct irritation and inhibition of prostaglandin synthesis (visualize prostaglandins as protective molecules). Combine both effects, illustrating severe gastric mucosal damage, erosion, or ulceration. A prominent 'WARNING: Increased Gastric Ulcer & Bleeding Risk' text flashes.
narration: However, combining Hydrocortisone with Aspirin significantly heightens gastric ulcer risk. Hydrocortisone decreases protective gastric mucus. Aspirin directly irritates the stomach lining and inhibits protective prostaglandins. This synergistic effect drastically increases the chance of bleeding and ulceration in the stomach.
